race.name: Salida 76
race.tagline: Salida 76. 76 miles of gravel through Salida.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Colorado Rockies. Significant elevation with mountain scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional CO event. Mountain terrain with good access, high altitude, and small regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Salida 76 is a regional event in Colorado—mountain terrain with significant elevation and high altitude. The Colorado Rockies are scenic and Salida is accessible, but the small regional field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional CO mountain gravel race. Worth it for CO/Mountain West riders. Not worth traveling far for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to CO—yes, it's solid. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better CO races: Crooked Gravel, Wild Horse Gravel, Bighorn Gravel.

logistics.food: Salida has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

course_description.signature_challenge: Colorado Rockies mountain terrain at high altitude.

non_negotiables.why: Colorado Rockies require sustained mountain effort.
Summer thunderstorms possible at high altitude.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with mountain terrain and high altitude.

logistics.explanation: Riverside Park start/finish in downtown Salida provides mountain town convenience, though late packet pickup morning-of is 'not recommended' by organizers. Race features cutoff times at 11:15am (Aid 1) and 1:15pm (Aid 2), after which riders must take the short course or ride unsupported.

length.explanation: One elite rider chose Salida after finding 'at my age and my fitness and my sanity and my grundle, that my limit is 100 miles or less' - the 76-mile distance fitting perfectly. The 12-13 mile opening climb delivers 3500 feet, getting 'almost 50% of the vert out of the way in the first 2 hours.' Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Anonymous rider puts it: "After much trial and error, I've found, at my age and my fitness and my sanity and my grundle, that my limit is 100 miles or less along with 10,000 feet of gain or less (preferably way less) and the s..."

technicality.explanation: Mid-race mud sections force riders onto 'packed down mud lanes, wide enough for a 45-50MM tire to teeter on' created by 170-180 riders ahead. Course features 'some spicy descents around mile 13 and mile 38' plus a final 'annoying, moderately hellacious' 12-13% headwall requiring absolute easiest gearing. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds. As Anonymous rider puts it: "Not long after Aid 2 is when the rain started up again. Again, remaining on the bike was a chore, but fortunately for us, roughly 170-180 riders had gone before us, providing packed down mud lanes, wi..."

elevation.explanation: The opening climb gains 3500 feet over 12-13 miles but 'wasn't insanely steep' according to one elite rider who appreciated getting nearly half the elevation out early. Community reports suggest the course reaches 10,000 feet, with the final climb featuring steep 12-13% gradients before the summit finish. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score. As Opening climb puts it: "The course started right at Riverside Park in town and quickly went up a road that quickly turned to dirt and the start of a 12-13 mile 3500' climb."

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 77°F and lows of 43°F, with a 19% chance of rain on any given day. 2025 race fell during 'the most precipitation of the summer, after what seemed like 40-50 straight days of sun.' Race morning started 'partly sunny and ideal temps' but rain resumed after Aid 2, creating challenging mud conditions that forced riders off established roads onto alpine tundra. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego. As Anonymous rider puts it: "Not long after Aid 2 is when the rain started up again. Again, remaining on the bike was a chore, but fortunately for us, roughly 170-180 riders had gone before us, providing packed down mud lanes, wi..."

altitude.explanation: Starting at 6,000 feet in Salida and climbing toward 10,000 feet affects pacing and gear choices. One elite rider noted managing altitude effects by working on 'relaxing my shoulders' during the extended opening climb that delivers significant elevation gain in the first two hours. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro.

adventure.explanation: Course explores unfamiliar terrain northeast of Salida that even experienced Colorado riders found unknown: 'I honestly knew nothing about the area NE of Salida, it had never registered on my radar.' The 76K accesses private McMurry family ranch land only available during race day.

prestige.explanation: Elite riders specifically choose Salida as a recovery race after harder efforts. One blogger selected it after finding his limits: 'at my age and my fitness and my sanity and my grundle, that my limit is 100 miles or less' - positioning Salida as manageable rather than prestigious.

race_quality.explanation: Race directors 'intelligently made the final 13 miles of the course untimed, since its all downhill and deterred anyone from going full bore and risking death.' Course includes full SAG support and paint mixer sticks for mud management, though weather can create challenging conditions. As Finish line amenities puts it: "Full SAG, medical and support, Mystery Swag, Finish food, beer and morning coffee"

experience.explanation: Post-race atmosphere extends beyond racing with locals offering late-night cruiser bike rides through downtown. One elite rider described his favorite section as 'just me, Ben and Kevin laughing and yelling deliriously, bombing through the mud, longing for a ray of sunshine.'

community.explanation: Field of 170-180 riders creates consistent group dynamics on remote terrain where 'this course is remote, beautiful, and ridden by few.' Proceeds benefit local high school mountain bike team and Salida Mountain Trails, with organizers noting they 'donate a substantial part of our earnings' to community projects.

field_depth.explanation: Field size of 170-180 riders provides adequate group riding but limited competitive depth. The race attracts riders seeking manageable distances rather than elite competition, with one participant noting the course fits riders who have found their limits at '100 miles or less.' Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Anonymous rider puts it: "Not long after Aid 2 is when the rain started up again. Again, remaining on the bike was a chore, but fortunately for us, roughly 170-180 riders had gone before us, providing packed down mud lanes, wi..."

value.explanation: $165 covers 76 miles with three aid stations, full SAG support, and finish festivities. The remote course accesses private ranch land 'only accessible during the race' and includes unique elements like paint mixer sticks for mud management plus post-race food, beer, and mystery swag.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $90-110. Salida avoids resort town pricing with downtown Riverside Park providing convenient race base. Race crew provides practical support like paint mixer sticks for mud clearing, though one rider found 'bombing down' dry downhills to fling mud clumps was more effective than the provided tools. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
